# Banking System Stability

Despite increased uncertainties in the global economy and financial markets, the Hong Kong banking system remained stable in 2018. The effectiveness of liquidity and credit risk management systems of authorized institutions continued to be a key focus of the Hong Kong Monetary Authority (HKMA) during the year. In view of the ongoing rise in cyber threats and the broader adoption of financial technology by the banking sector, the HKMA strengthened its supervision of technology risk management and business continuity capabilities of authorized institutions. In May, the HKMA issued a revised version of the "Guidelines on the Authorization of Virtual Banks" and began processing applications for virtual bank authorization. In terms of conduct supervision, the HKMA took further measures to strengthen oversight of authorized institutions' practices in selling investment and insurance products, promote accessible banking services for people with disabilities, and foster a customer-centric corporate culture.

As financial crimes become more complex and globalized, the Hong Kong Monetary Authority continues to enhance Hong Kong's capacity to combat money laundering and terrorist financing through the adoption of new technologies and risk-based approaches. The Authority has made satisfactory progress in implementing international regulatory standards, including capital adequacy standards, disclosure standards, liquidity standards, and large risk exposure limits. In addition, the Authority has strengthened communication and engagement with the banking sector to ensure an appropriate balance between regulatory effectiveness and market development.

At the same time, the Hong Kong Monetary Authority continues to strive to ensure that Hong Kong has a credible resolution mechanism for authorized institutions, including introducing rules on minimum loss-absorbing capacity requirements to address a major obstacle facing the feasibility of resolving authorized institutions.

# Objective

One of the Hong Kong Monetary Authority's overall objectives is to promote the safety and stability of the banking system. To achieve this objective, it is essential to establish and maintain a financial system with high resilience that can provide the necessary critical financial services for the Hong Kong economy.

Banks may affect the stability of the banking system due to their operational practices, or even in extreme cases, due to disorderly collapses. As a regulatory authority, the Financial Services and Treasury Bureau plays an important role in ensuring financial stability by ensuring that banks are capable of withstanding shocks, responding to crises, and recovering to normal operations, ultimately helping to prevent collapses. The Financial Services and Treasury Bureau is responsible for prudential supervision of banks, as well as licensing and regulating authorized institutions in Hong Kong, including licensed banks, restricted licensed banks, and deposit-taking companies (collectively referred to as "authorized institutions"). The Financial Services and Treasury Bureau also oversees the designation and regulation of certain financial market infrastructures.

However, the Financial Secretary cannot guarantee that the financial system is entirely free of risks, and Hong Kong's prudent regulatory regime is not designed to ensure "zero risk." As one of the resolution mechanisms, the Financial Secretary aims to ensure that, once an authorized institution is no longer viable, its collapse can be handled in an orderly manner. To this end, Hong Kong has established a financial institution resolution mechanism, under which the Financial Secretary serves as the resolution authority for a number of financial institutions, including authorized institutions. To establish an efficient Hong Kong resolution mechanism, it is necessary to formulate resolution legislation and policy standards, conduct resolution planning to remove obstacles to the feasibility of resolving authorized institutions, and build the operational capacity of the Hong Kong Monetary Authority to resolve non-viable authorized institutions. To effectively carry out the aforementioned tasks, the Hong Kong Monetary Authority needs to adopt methods that are consistent with and coordinated with international practices.

# 2018 Year in Review

# Overview of Regulatory Work

In 2018, the HKMA conducted a total of 187 on-site inspections, covering a wide range of areas including the CAMEL rating of authorized institutions, corporate governance, business operations, risk management, and the business strategies of authorized institutions in response to the development of financial technology. To further enhance the risk management standards of authorized institutions, the HKMA held 27 meetings with the boards of directors or board committees of authorized institutions, and followed up on the progress of authorized institutions in implementing corporate governance guidelines. In addition, the HKMA held 28 tripartite meetings with authorized institutions and their external auditors.

In addition to off-site reviews, the HKMA continues to conduct regular on-site inspections and complements them with thematic assessments to examine areas deemed to be of higher risk. During the year, the HKMA carried out a total of 392 on-site inspections and thematic assessments, with credit risk management remaining the main focus of the reviews and assessments. Other key areas included technology risk and operational risk management, as well as measures to combat money laundering and terrorist financing. The HKMA also increased the number of on-site inspections and thematic assessments on liquidity and market risk management, as well as the implementation of the Basel capital adequacy framework. Special review teams also conducted on-site inspections of authorized institutions' businesses related to securities, investment products, insurance, and mandatory Provident Fund (MPF) matters.

Table 1 presents a summary of the Hong Kong Monetary Authority's supervisory work in 2018.

# Supervision of Credit Risk

# Credit Growth and Asset Quality

Credit growth slowed in 2018, with total loan amount increasing by 4.4% for the year, compared to a 16.1% increase in 2017 (Table 2). Trade financing decreased by 7.6% in 2018. The slower growth in loans was mainly due to the increasingly uncertain global economic and trade environment, leading to a contraction in credit demand.

Table 2 Growth of Loans and Advances

The total amount of related loans in the mainland increased by 1.4% to HKD 424.9 billion at the end of 2018, which was lower than the growth rate in 2017 (Table 3).

Table 3 Growth in Domestic-related Loans

The asset quality of the authorized institutions remained stable in 2018. The specific classified loan ratio for retail banking decreased from 0.56% at the end of 2017 to 0.50% at the end of 2018, significantly below the long-term average of 2.1% since 2000; during the same period, the specific classified loan ratio for the entire banking sector declined from 0.68% to 0.55%. Regarding loans related to the mainland, the specific classified loan ratio for retail banking decreased from 0.75% to 0.63% in 2018, while the relevant ratio for the entire banking sector also fell from 0.67% a year earlier to 0.54%.

Within the year, the Monetary Authority strengthened its supervision to ensure that authorized institutions continue to adopt prudent credit risk management standards. In particular, the Monetary Authority actively investigated the backgrounds and structures of large enterprises, thereby enhancing the monitoring system for corporate credit risks. Additionally, the Monetary Authority conducted special assessments focusing on key credit risk management monitoring measures, such as the approval criteria and risk management for large enterprise loans, loan classification and provisioning systems, credit risk governance frameworks, risk management for property developers' loans, secured loans, and loan collateralized by policies.

# Mortgage Loan for Property

Residential property prices reached a historical high in July 2018, but showed signs of easing in the second half of the year. The Hong Kong Monetary Authority's eight rounds of countercyclical macro-prudential measures introduced since October 2009 have enhanced the Hong Kong banking system's ability to withstand potential reversals in the local property market. The average mortgage loan-to-value ratio for new residential mortgages dropped from 64% in September 2009, before the first round of countercyclical measures, to 46% in December 2018. The average debt service-to-income ratio also fell from 41% in August 2010, when the relevant ceiling was first introduced, to 34% in December 2018 (Figure 1).

Figure 1: Average Mortgage Loan-to-Value Ratio and Repayment-to-Income Ratio for Newly Constructed Residential Mortgages

# Supervision of Operational and Technology Risks

The technology-related risks faced by the banking sector remain relatively high. The Hong Kong Monetary Authority introduced the "Cybersecurity Assessment Framework" in 2016. The first phase implementation plan covered 30 authorized institutions, including all major banks, which have completed three stages of assessment: self-assessment of risk levels, maturity assessment, and (if applicable) risk-led cyber attack and defense simulation tests. These assessments have helped authorized institutions identify areas requiring improvement and take remedial actions to enhance their cybersecurity defenses. Meanwhile, the Hong Kong Monetary Authority has also established a timetable for the second and third phases of implementation, which will cover the remaining authorized institutions. This year, the Hong Kong Monetary Authority conducted on-site reviews, focusing on the cybersecurity controls, outsourcing arrangements, and information technology governance of authorized institutions.

# Smart Bank

The HKMA continues to work with the banking sector to implement the seven measures promoting smart banking, which were announced in September 2017, in order to promote the development of financial technology in Hong Kong. On the regulatory front, the HKMA issued a revised version of the "Guidelines on the Recognition of Virtual Banks" in May. In addition, under the "Banking Easy" initiative, the HKMA has simplified the regulatory requirements related to remote account opening, online loans, and online wealth management. These optimized regulatory requirements help banks provide a better online banking user experience. In September, the scope of the "Banking Easy" initiative was expanded to promote the adoption of financial compliance technology (Regtech) by banks. Among the three new focus areas are: (1) compliance technology for monitoring money laundering and terrorist financing, (2) compliance technology for prudential risk management and compliance, and (3) "machine-readable" regulatory requirements.

Mr. Man Kuet Hung, Deputy Governor of the Hong Kong Monetary Authority, delivered a speech titled "Financial Compliance Technology in the New Era of Smart Banking" at the "Hong Kong Bankers' Summit 2018" hosted by the Hong Kong Bankers' Association.

# Regulation of Liquidity and Market Risks

As the U.S. monetary policy continues to normalize, the Authority has strengthened its supervision of liquidity risk to ensure that authorized institutions prudently and effectively manage their liquidity risks. This year, the Authority conducted a round of thematic assessments to evaluate the preparedness of authorized institutions for potential tightening of dollar liquidity and their capacity to conduct internal liquidity stress tests. In addition, the Authority has monitored compliance by authorized institutions with the "Net Stable Funding Ratio" requirement, which came into effect in January.

The HKMA not only reviews the market risk management of authorized institutions' bond portfolios but also conducted a special on-site inspection on the margin and risk mitigation standards under the Global Foreign Exchange Code and non-central clearing over-the-counter derivatives, to examine the extent to which authorized institutions comply with the new international standards in their treasury operations.

# Combating Money Laundering and Terrorist Financing

The Government's "Risk Assessment Report on Money Laundering and Terrorist Financing in Hong Kong," published in April, pointed out that the Hong Kong banking system faces high money laundering threats, similar to other international financial centers, reflecting the increasing globalization and complexity of financial services. The money laundering threats facing Hong Kong come not only from local criminal activities but, to a greater extent, from overseas activities. These overseas activities include illicit proceeds from corruption abroad, fraudulent activities by transnational criminal groups, tax evasion, and risks related to sanctions, stemming from Hong Kong's status as a payment and trade hub. With the assistance of the Hong Kong Monetary Authority, the Government has formulated a policy statement on combating money laundering and terrorist financing, outlining responses to these threats. The objective is to enhance the system's capacity to combat money laundering and terrorist financing while also attracting and facilitating legitimate business activities.

The Anti-Money Laundering and Counter-Terrorist Financing (Financial Institutions) (Amendment) Ordinance 2018 came into effect on March 1, introducing amendments that provide flexibility in verifying customer identities to accommodate the development of technology-enabled customer onboarding by authorized institutions. The new legislation also broadens the scope of application, requiring lawyers, accountants, real estate agents, and trust or company service providers to take responsibility for combating money laundering and terrorist financing, thereby comprehensively strengthening the anti-money laundering and counter-terrorist financing regime. These amendments, together with the amendments to the Companies Ordinance aimed at enhancing transparency of beneficial ownership of companies, will assist authorized institutions in carrying out their work against money laundering and terrorist financing.

To strengthen and further enhance communication with authorized institutions on anti-money laundering and counter-terrorist financing policies and supervisory approaches, the Hong Kong Monetary Authority issued in October a new section titled "Supervisory Approach to Anti-Money Laundering and Counter-Terrorist Financing" under the "Regulatory Policy Manual," as well as the updated "Guidelines on Anti-Money Laundering and Counter-Terrorist Financing (for Authorized Institutions)" in line with relevant legislative amendments. This aims to more effectively implement a risk-based approach and reduce obstacles for authorized institutions in adopting new technologies to comply with anti-money laundering and counter-terrorist financing regimes.

The role of information exchange in combating money laundering and terrorist financing has become increasingly important. With the support of the Hong Kong Monetary Authority and the Hong Kong Bankers' Association (Bankers' Association), the banking sector has actively participated in the Financial Intelligence Unit Task Force (Task Force) on anti-money laundering and counter-terrorism financing, achieving substantial results. A review of the Task Force's pilot program was initiated at the end of 2018 and is expected to be completed in early 2019.

# 香港的國際金融中心地位

鞏固香港的國際金融中心地位是金管局主要職責之一。旨在促進銀行及支付業界開發與應用金融科技的7項措施，於年內取得良好進展，最佳例子是快速支付系統「轉數快」成功推出。

中國內地與香港資本市場的互聯互通計劃推出優化措施，以及粵港澳大灣區的發展，令香港作為進入中國內地主要門戶的獨特地位進一步加強。香港作為全球離岸人民幣業務樞紐的地位亦更為穩固，本港人民幣金融活動蓬勃發展。

與此同時，金管局致力開拓新機遇，進一步提升香港金融平台的競爭力，包括基建融資、企業財資中心及綠色債券市場。金管局亦加強向海外及內地持份者宣傳香港優勢的市場推廣計劃。在國際層面，金管局於多個區內及國際委員會扮演領導角色，明確體現了香港在相關國際工作的專業知識及承擔。

# 概覽

為加強香港作為亞洲金融科技樞紐的地位，金管局致力落實於2017年9月公布、旨在促進銀行及支付行業開發與應用金融科技的7項措施。該7項推動智慧銀行的措施於年內取得的主要進展包括：

- 成功推出快速支付系統「轉數快」，全面接通不同銀行及儲值支付工具（統稱「電子錢包」）
- 發布銀行業開放應用程式介面（開放API）框架及促進業界落實開放API；
- 提升金融科技研究及人才培訓；
- 加強跨境金融科技合作；
- 修訂《虛擬銀行的認可》指引，並處理虛擬銀行牌照申請；
- 「金融科技監管沙盒」升級版（FSS 2.0）運作順暢；及
- 擴展「銀行易」以促進銀行採用金融合規科技。

金管局轄下金融科技促進辦公室(FFO)，聯同金管局各銀行部門在推動落實上述措施方面擔當重要角色。

隨着中國內地與香港資本市場的互聯互通計劃優化措施的落實，香港作為進入中國內地主要門戶的獨特地位進一步加強。「債券通」全面實施即時貨銀兩訖(DvP)結算模式及國務院宣布境外投資者投資中國境內債券市場的稅務寛免安排，進一步提升計劃的效率及吸引力。金管局亦與內地當局緊密合作，探討及實施多項金融配套措施，便利在粵港澳大灣區（大灣區）生活、工作及營商的個人和企業。香港離岸人民幣業務繼續蓬勃發展，人民幣存款資金池全年上升6%至6,577億元人民幣；人民幣即時支付結算(RTGS)系統平均每日交易額達到10,101億元人民幣的高水平。

金管局積極開拓進一步提升香港金融平台競爭力的新機會。為促進香港債券市場的發展，金管局落實《財政預算案》所提出的「債券資助先導計劃」，為首次在香港發行債券的機構提供資助，並與政府緊密合作修訂法例，擴大「合資格債務票據計劃」下可獲稅務豁免的債券投資收入範圍。金管局亦加強市場推廣活動，向海外及內地持份者宣傳香港的優勢，包括舉辦多項大型及專題外展活動推廣香港為綠色金融、基建融資及企業財資中心樞紐。

在國際層面，金管局領導多個區內及國際委員會。金管局現正擔任金融穩定理事會轄下監管合作常設委員會主席、巴塞爾銀行監管委員會（巴塞爾委員會）轄下監管及實施準則小組，以及東亞及太平洋地區中央銀行會議(EMEAP) 轄下金融市場工作小組主席。

香港金融基建的安全及有效運作，為香港作為國際金融中心的地位奠定穩固基礎。處理銀行同業交易的4個RTGS系統、債務工具中央結算系統（CMU系統）及香港交易資料儲存庫（香港儲存庫）在2018年達到100%的系統可供使用率，高於99.95%的目標水平。透過於內地兩個中央證券託管機構的帳戶，CMU系統繼續協助結算「債券通」北向通交易，以及替相關CMU系統成員持有內地債務證券。

為促進零售支付業的整體安全及效率，金管局於8月根據《支付系統及儲值支付工具條例》（《支付條例》）指定多兩個零售支付系統，使其運作受到金管局監察。迄今受金管局監察的指定零售支付系統增至6個。金管局亦對16個儲值支付工具持牌人進行監管。有關持牌人積極推出新產品及服務，致力為客戶提供更多選擇及更佳的用戶體驗。與此同時，電子支票與電子帳單及繳費服務涵蓋範圍，進一步擴展至包括香港與整個廣東省的跨境支付交易。

# 2018年回顧

# 香港作為亞洲的金融科技樞紐

# 推動智慧銀行的措施

金管局於2017年9月公布7項推動智慧銀行的措施，旨在協助銀行業提升至更高層次，並把握銀行與科技結合帶來的龐大機遇。金管局於年內在落實這些措施及為香港金融生態轉型方面，進展良好。

# 「轉數快」

「轉數快」於9月成功啟動，方便銀行及儲值支付工具用戶隨時隨地進行港元及人民幣的跨行即時資金轉帳，用戶只需輸入收款人的手機號碼或電郵地址。共有21間銀行（包括大部分零售銀行）及10間儲值支付工具營運商已加入該系統，為客戶提供即時支付服務及╱或帳戶綁定服務。

「轉數快」在3.5個月內已接獲超過200萬個登記，相對香港人口比例27%。該系統自推出以來處理超過480萬宗交易，涉及總額逾1,049億港元及27.5億元人民幣。

金管局於同月推出香港零售支付共用二維碼標準及相關流動應用程式「香港共用二維碼」(HKQR)，是全球首創將多個二維碼整合成為個綜合二維碼的流動應用程式，方便商戶尤其中小企以同一個二維碼接受不同支付服務營運商的支付方案，無需向客戶展示多個二維碼。

# 開放應用程式介面

開放API是指透過向第三方服務供應商開放銀行的相關數據，更好更方便地融合銀行與其他行業的服務。用家單用一個系統就能在安全環境下享受綜合服務。為促進銀行界研發及提供開放API，金管局於7月發布開放API框架。該框架採用風險為本原則，並分4個階段落實各項開放API功能。截至2019年1月底，20間銀行已開放第一階段約500個開放API接口，涵蓋逾1,000項產品及服務的資料。

# 科研及人才培訓

建基於金管局主導的貿易融資概念驗證成果由香港多間銀行組成的聯盟於10月啟動以分布式分類帳技術(DLT)為基礎的貿易融資平台「貿易聯動」。該平台旨在透過數碼化貿易文件及自動化貿易融資流程，減低失誤及詐騙風險。截至2018年底，已有12間銀行加入成為該聯盟成員。「貿易聯動」與歐洲貿易融資平台「we.trade」於10月簽署《諒解備忘錄》，進行對接雙方平台的概念驗證。金管局亦同步探討「貿易聯動」與其他地區對接的機會，包括與新加坡金融管理局合作推出「全球貿易連接網絡」。

金管局總裁陳德霖先生（左）於「貿易聯動」啟動儀式上。

為培育更多金融科技專才，金管局於1月與香港應用科技研究院（應科院）合作推出「金融科技人才培育計劃」升級版(FCAS 2.0)。FCAS 2.0設有4個項目，適合處於不同職涯發展階段的年輕人才。計劃下有200多名學生受惠。

金管局總裁陳德霖先生（左二）與數碼港主席林家禮博士（左一）、香港應科院主席王明鑫先生（右二）及香港科技園公司行政總裁黃克強先生（右一）出席FCAS 2.0啟動儀式。

# 跨境合作

繼於2017年與深圳市人民政府金融發展服務辦公室（深圳金融辦）簽署《諒解備忘錄》後，金管局繼續加強與深圳的金融科技合作。當中包括金管局贊助「深圳金融科技暑期實習計劃」，讓50名學生到深圳多間著名公司進行為期6星期的實習，體驗當地的金融科技生態；另與深圳金融辦第二次合辦「深港金融科技創新獎」。

金管局副總裁李達志先生（右二）與首批深圳金融科技暑期實習生交談。

金管局亦於2018年與瑞士金融市場監督管理局、波蘭金融監管局、阿布扎比國際金融中心金融服務監管局及巴西中央銀行簽署金融科技合作協議，促進金融科技合作。

在8月，金管局與11間金融監管當局和相關機構公布「全球金融創新網絡」計劃。該網絡旨在為創新型公司提供更有效方式與監管機構進行互動，並促進監管機構之間就創新相關議題的合作。

# 虛擬銀行

引入虛擬銀行將會為香港金融科技應用增添新動力，並為數碼銀行客戶帶來嶄新體驗。虛擬銀行以個人或中小企等零售客戶為對象，因此亦有助促進普及金融。經公眾諮詢，金管局於5月發出《虛擬銀行的認可》指引修訂本，並於8月底接獲約30宗申請。

# 金融科技監管沙盒

年內沙盒的使用穩步上升。為協助建立金融合規科技的生態系統，沙盒於9月起開放予金融合規科技的項目。

截至2018年底，共有42項金融科技或科技產品獲准使用沙盒進行測試，其中28項已完成試行，有關產品亦已於其後推出市場。金管局另接獲220項使用「金融科技監管聊天室」的個案，希望在金融科技項目構思初期取得監管反饋意見。其中有約70%的個案來自科技公司。

# Hong Kong's Status as an International Financial Center

Strengthening Hong Kong's position as an international financial center is one of the Hong Kong Monetary Authority's main responsibilities. Seven measures aimed at promoting the development and application of financial technology in the banking and payment sectors have made good progress this year, with a notable example being the successful launch of the fast payment system "FPS (hongbao)."

The initiative for enhanced connectivity between China's mainland and Hong Kong capital markets, along with the development of the Guangdong-Hong Kong-Macao Greater Bay Area, has further strengthened Hong Kong's unique position as a gateway to China's mainland. Hong Kong's status as an offshore RMB business hub has also become more solidified, with vibrant RMB financial activities in the city.

At the same time, the Hong Kong Monetary Authority is committed to exploring new opportunities to further enhance the competitiveness of Hong Kong's financial platform, including infrastructure financing, corporate treasury centers, and the green bond market. The Authority has also intensified its market promotion initiatives to publicize Hong Kong's advantages to overseas and mainland stakeholders. On the international level, the Authority plays a leading role in various regional and international committees, clearly demonstrating Hong Kong's professional expertise and commitment in relevant international matters.

# Overview

To strengthen Hong Kong's position as a financial technology hub in Asia, the Hong Kong Monetary Authority has been actively implementing the seven measures announced in September 2017, aimed at promoting the development and application of financial technology in the banking and payment sectors. The main progress achieved during the year in the seven initiatives to advance smart banking includes:

- Successfully launched the fast payment system "Zhangshu Kuai", fully connecting with different banks and value-added payment tools (collectively referred to as "e-wallets")  
- Released the framework for open application programming interfaces (open API) in the banking industry and promoted the implementation of open API across the sector;  
- Enhanced research on financial technology and talent training;  
- Strengthened cross-border cooperation in financial technology;  
- Revised the "Guidelines on the Recognition of Virtual Banks" and processed virtual bank license applications;  
- The upgraded version of the "Financial Technology Regulatory Sandbox" (FSS 2.0) is operating smoothly; and  
- Expanded "Banking Easy" to promote the adoption of financial compliance technology by banks.

The Financial Services and Treasury Bureau's Financial Technology Promotion Office (FFO), together with the bureau's various banking departments, plays an important role in promoting and implementing the aforementioned measures.

With the implementation of optimized measures under the cross-border capital market connectivity initiatives between mainland China and Hong Kong, Hong Kong's unique position as a key gateway to mainland China has been further strengthened. The "Bond Connect" program has fully adopted the real-time gross settlement (DvP) settlement mechanism, and the State Council has announced tax exemption arrangements for overseas investors investing in China's domestic bond market, further enhancing the program's efficiency and appeal. The Hong Kong Monetary Authority has also closely collaborated with mainland authorities to explore and implement various financial supporting measures, facilitating individuals and businesses living, working, and operating in the Guangdong-Hong Kong-Macau Greater Bay Area (GBA). Offshore RMB business in Hong Kong continues to thrive, with the total RMB deposit funds pool increasing by 6% year-on-year to 657.7 billion RMB; the average daily transaction volume of the RMB real-time gross settlement (RTGS) system reached a high level of 10,101 billion RMB.

The Hong Kong Monetary Authority actively explores new opportunities to further enhance the competitiveness of Hong Kong's financial platform. To promote the development of Hong Kong's bond market, the Authority has implemented the "Bond Grant Pilot Scheme" proposed in the Budget, providing grants to institutions issuing bonds for the first time in Hong Kong. It has also closely collaborated with the government to revise relevant legislation, expanding the scope of bond investment income eligible for tax exemption under the "Qualifying Debt Instruments Scheme." In addition, the Authority has intensified market promotion activities, promoting Hong Kong's advantages to overseas and mainland stakeholders, including organizing various large-scale and specialized outreach events to position Hong Kong as a hub for green finance, infrastructure financing, and corporate treasury centers.

At the international level, the Monetary Authority leads multiple regional and international committees. The Monetary Authority is currently serving as the chair of the Committee on Banking Supervision under the Financial Stability Board, the Regulatory and Implementation Standards Group under the Basel Committee on Banking Supervision, and the Financial Markets Working Group under the East Asia and Pacific Central Banks Meeting (EMEAP).

The secure and efficient operation of Hong Kong's financial infrastructure forms a solid foundation for Hong Kong's status as an international financial center. In 2018, four RTGS systems handling bank interbank transactions, the Debt Securities Central Clearing System (CMU System), and the Hong Kong Trading Data Repository (Hong Kong Repository) achieved a system availability rate of 100%, exceeding the target level of 99.95%. The CMU System continued to assist in settling "Bond Connect" Northbound transactions through accounts with two central securities depositories in mainland China, and also held mainland debt securities on behalf of relevant CMU System members.

To promote the overall security and efficiency of the retail payment industry, the Hong Kong Monetary Authority (HKMA) designated two more retail payment systems in August under the Payment Systems and Stored Value Facilities Ordinance (the "Payment Ordinance"), subjecting them to HKMA supervision. As a result, the number of designated retail payment systems under HKMA supervision has increased to six. The HKMA also exercises regulatory oversight over 16 licensed stored value facility operators. These licensed operators actively launch new products and services, striving to offer customers more choices and a better user experience. Meanwhile, the scope of electronic cheques and electronic bill and payment services has further expanded to include cross-border payment transactions between Hong Kong and the entire Guangdong Province.

# 2018 Year in Review

# Hong Kong as the Financial Technology Hub of Asia

# Measures to Promote Smart Banking

The HKMA announced seven measures to promote smart banking in September 2017, aiming to help the banking sector reach a higher level and seize the significant opportunities brought by the integration of banking and technology. Throughout the year, the HKMA has made good progress in implementing these measures and transforming Hong Kong's financial ecosystem.

# "Fast turnover"

"Fast Transfer" was successfully launched in September, enabling banks and value-added payment tool users to make real-time interbank transfers of Hong Kong dollars and RMB anytime and anywhere. Users only need to enter the recipient's mobile phone number or email address. A total of 21 banks (including most retail banks) and 10 value-added payment tool operators have joined the system, providing customers with real-time payment services and/or account binding services.

"Fast processing" has received over 20 million registrations within 3.5 months, equivalent to 27% of Hong Kong's population. Since its launch, the system has processed over 48 million transactions, involving a total amount of more than 104.9 billion Hong Kong dollars and 2.75 billion yuan.

The Hong Kong Monetary Authority launched the Hong Kong Retail Payment Common QR Code Standard and the related mobile application "Hong Kong Common QR Code" (HKQR) in the same month. It is the world's first mobile application that integrates multiple QR codes into a single comprehensive QR code, making it convenient for businesses, especially small and medium enterprises, to accept payment solutions from different payment service providers using the same QR code, without having to display multiple QR codes to customers.

# Open Application Programming Interface

Open API refers to the practice of opening up a bank's relevant data to third-party service providers, enabling better and more convenient integration of banking services with those of other industries. Users can enjoy comprehensive services in a secure environment through a single system. To promote the development and provision of open APIs in the banking sector, the Hong Kong Monetary Authority released an Open API framework in July. The framework adopts a risk-based approach and implements various Open API functions in four stages. As of the end of January 2019, approximately 500 Open API interfaces in the first stage had been opened by 20 banks, covering data on more than 1,000 products and services.

# Research and Talent Training

A trade financing platform named "TradeLink" was launched in October by an alliance of several Hong Kong banks, based on the results of a trade financing concept validation led by the Hong Kong Monetary Authority. The platform aims to reduce errors and fraud risks through digital trade documents and automated trade financing processes. By the end of 2018, 12 banks had joined the alliance. In October, "TradeLink" signed a Memorandum of Understanding with the European trade financing platform "we.trade" to conduct a concept validation integration between the two platforms. The Hong Kong Monetary Authority also simultaneously explored opportunities for "TradeLink" to connect with other regions, including collaborating with the Monetary Authority of Singapore to launch the "Global Trade Connect Network."

Mr. Chan Tak-lun, Governor of the Hong Kong Monetary Authority (left), at the launch ceremony of "Trade Linkage".

To cultivate more fintech professionals, the Hong Kong Monetary Authority (HKMA) launched the upgraded "Fintech Talent Development Program" (FCAS 2.0) in January in collaboration with the Hong Kong Applied Science and Technology Research Institute (ASTRI). FCAS 2.0 consists of four programs suitable for young talents at different career development stages. Over 200 students have benefited from the program.

Mr. Chan Tak-lun, Governor of the Hong Kong Monetary Authority (second from the left), Mr. Lam Ka-lik, Chairman of Digital Harbour (first from the left), Mr. Wang Ming-sin, Chairman of the Hong Kong Institute of Applied Sciences (second from the right), and Mr. Huang Ke-qiang, Chief Executive of the Hong Kong Science and Technology Parks Corporation (first from the right) attended the FCAS 2.0 launch ceremony.

# Cross-border Collaboration

Following the signing of a Memorandum of Understanding with the Shenzhen Municipal People's Government Financial Development Service Office (Shenzhen Financial Office) in 2017, the Hong Kong Monetary Authority has continued to strengthen its collaboration with Shenzhen in financial technology. This includes the Hong Kong Monetary Authority's sponsorship of the "Shenzhen Financial Technology Summer Internship Program," which allows 50 students to undertake a six-week internship at several well-known companies in Shenzhen, experiencing the local financial technology ecosystem. Additionally, the Hong Kong Monetary Authority co-organized the "Shenzhen-Hong Kong Financial Technology Innovation Awards" for the second time with the Shenzhen Financial Office.

Mr. Li Dazhi, Deputy Governor of the Monetary Authority (second from the right), is talking with the first batch of Shenzhen Financial Technology Summer Interns.

The HKMA also signed fintech cooperation agreements with the Swiss Financial Market Supervisory Authority, the Polish Financial Supervision Authority, the Abu Dhabi Global Market Financial Services Regulatory Authority, and the Central Bank of Brazil in 2018 to promote fintech collaboration.

In August, the Hong Kong Monetary Authority, together with 11 financial regulatory authorities and related organizations, launched the "Global Financial Innovation Network" initiative. This network aims to provide innovative companies with more effective ways to interact with regulatory authorities and to promote cooperation among regulatory bodies on issues related to innovation.

# Virtual Banking

Introducing virtual banks will bring new momentum to Hong Kong's fintech applications and offer digital bank customers a fresh experience. As virtual banks target retail customers such as individuals and small and medium-sized enterprises, they will also help promote financial inclusion. Following public consultations, the Hong Kong Monetary Authority issued the revised "Guidelines on the Recognition of Virtual Banks" in May and received about 30 applications by the end of August.

# Financial Technology Regulatory Sandbox

The usage of the sandbox has steadily increased throughout the year. To help establish an ecosystem for financial compliance technology, the sandbox was opened to financial compliance technology projects starting in September.

By the end of 2018, a total of 42 financial technology or technological products had been approved to undergo testing through the sandbox, of which 28 had completed their trials and the related products had subsequently been launched to the market. The Authority also received 220 cases seeking to use the "Financial Technology Regulatory Chatroom" to obtain regulatory feedback at the early stage of fintech project development. Approximately 70% of these cases came from technology companies.

# 儲備管理

2018年對投資者而言是困難的一年，投資環境備受多項風險因素困擾，包括美國利率持續正常化引發金融狀況收緊、主要經濟體之間的貿易摩擦升級，以及全球多處民粹主義抬頭及地緣政治風險加劇。環球股市普遍向下，美國國庫券收益率亦隨着美國聯邦儲備局4次加息而上升。在美息趨升下，美元轉強。部分新興市場面對國內嚴峻的政治及經濟壓力，其貨幣顯著下挫。儘管投資環境充滿挑戰，外匯基金在2018年仍錄得109億港元投資收入。

# 外匯基金

根據《外匯基金條例》，外匯基金的首要目的是直接或間接影響港元匯價，亦可運用於保持香港貨幣及金融體系穩定健全，藉此保持香港作為國際金融中心的地位。金管局根據財政司司長轉授的權力及轉授權力的條款，就外匯基金的運用及投資管理向財政司司長負責。

# 外匯基金的管理

# 投資目標及組合架構

外匯基金諮詢委員會為外匯基金制定下列投資目標：

(a) 保障資本；
(b) 確保整體貨幣基礎在任何時候都由流通性極高的美元資產提供十足支持；
(c) 確保流動資金足以維持貨幣及金融穩定；以及
(d) 在符合上述(a)至(c)項的前提下盡量爭取投資回報，以保障基金的長期購買力。

以上目標全面顧及外匯基金的法定目的，並已於外匯基金的組合結構及目標資產配置中反映。

外匯基金大致上分成兩個主要組合：支持組合及投資組合。支持組合持有流通性極高的美元資產，按照貨幣發行局制度的規定為貨幣基礎提供十足支持。投資組合主要投資於經濟合作與發展組織成員國的債市及股市，以保障資產的價值及長期購買力。

為能更妥善管理風險及提高中長期回報，金管局以審慎及循序漸進方式將外匯基金的部分資產分散投資至較多元化的資產類別，包括新興巿場及內地債券與股票、私募股權（包括基建）及房地產。新興巿場及內地債券與股票由投資組合持有，私募股權及房地產投資則由長期增長組合持有。長期增長組合的市值上限為外匯基金累計盈餘的三分之一及未來基金與外匯基金附屬公司存款中與長期增長組合掛鈎部分的總和。

策略性資產組合於2007年設立，以持有政府基於策略性目的而為外匯基金帳目購入的香港交易及結算所有限公司股份。由於這個組合性質獨特，因此外匯基金的投資表現評估並無將其包括在內。

# 於外匯基金的存款

外匯基金不時接受財政儲備、政府基金及法定組織的存款，利率一般與投資組合的表現掛鈎，但主要以未來基金除外。未來基金存款的利率與投資組合及長期增長組合的表現掛鈎，實際利率視乎組合比重而定。於2018年底，未來基金在投資組合與長期增長組合的比重約為50:50。

# 投資程序

外匯基金的投資程序分別以策略性資產配置及戰略性資產配置作基礎。策略性資產配置，即投資基準反映的配置情況，顯示外匯基金為達到投資目標而可作出的長線資產配置。外匯基金以策略性配置作為指引，對資產進行戰略性配置，以爭取超越基準的回報。因此，實際配置往往會與基準配置（亦即策略性配置）有所偏離，而實際與基準配置之間的差距稱為「戰略性偏離」。財政司司長經諮詢外匯基金諮詢委員會後制定投資基準及循跡誤差限額，金管局獲授權決定戰略性資產配置及定出戰略性偏離的容許範圍。投資組合經理可在戰略性偏離的容許範圍內選持倉盤，從短期市場變化中獲利。

# 投資管理

# 直接投資

金管局於8月成立外匯基金投資辦公室，專責投資及相關風險管理職能。該辦公室職員負責直接管理外匯基金約72%的投資，包括整個支持組合及部分投資組合。該部分的投資組合投資於環球定息市場，並透過衍生工具執行外匯基金的宏觀風險管理策略。

# 外聘投資經理

除透過內部職員管理資產外，金管局亦僱用外聘投資經理負責管理外匯基金約28%的資產，包括所有上市股票組合及其他特別資產。僱用外聘投資經理的目的是要運用市場上最佳的專業投資技術為外匯基金投資，以取得可持續回報，並讓外匯基金受惠於多元化及互補的投資方式，以及汲取市場心得與專業投資技術知識。

僱用外聘投資經理的相關支出包括基金管理與託管費、交易費、預扣稅及其他稅項。這些支出主要受市場因素影響而每年不同。

# 風險管理及監察

投資環境越趨複雜，突顯風險管理的重要。金管局為內部及外聘投資經理所管理的投資組合均訂立嚴格管控措施及投資指引，並密切監察對指引及法規的遵守情況。金管局已加強風險評估，以配合外匯基金越趨多元化的投資；另採用風險管控工具來評估在正常及極度不利市況下的市場風險。金管局亦進行詳細的投資表現因素分析，以識別促成不同表現的成因，藉此評估如何充分利用內部及外聘投資經理的投資管理技術。

# 負責任投資

金管局支持負責任投資。例如，金管局已採納證券及期貨事務監察委員會公布的《負責任的擁有權原則》。該套原則旨在協助投資者釐定如何以最佳方法履行其於香港上市公司投資的擁有權責任。就外匯基金的管理而言，金管局已就環境、社會及管治因素制定內部指引，適用於外聘基金經理的甄選、委任及監察程序。獲委任負責主動式管理香港股票組合的外聘基金經理，須在管理有關投資時遵守《負責任的擁有權原則》。整體而言，金管局已將環境、社會及管治因素納入投資及相關監察活動的內部程序。金管局會密切注視環境、社會及管治因素的相關標準的發展，並評估如何能夠將這些標準進一步融入投資程序。此外，為促進負責任投資的國際合作，金管局已成為非牟利組織FCLTGlobal的成員，該組織旨在推動長遠目標為本的業務及投資決定。

# Inventory Management

2018 was a challenging year for investors, as the investment environment was troubled by various risk factors, including the tightening of financial conditions caused by the continued normalization of U.S. interest rates, the escalation of trade frictions among major economies, and the rise of populism and increased geopolitical risks in various parts of the world. Global stock markets generally declined, and U.S. Treasury yields rose along with the four interest rate hikes by the Federal Reserve. With U.S. interest rates rising, the dollar strengthened. Some emerging markets faced severe political and economic pressures domestically, leading to significant depreciation of their currencies. Despite the challenging investment environment, the Exchange Fund still recorded HK$10.9 billion in investment income in 2018.

# Hong Kong Monetary Authority

According to the Exchange Fund Ordinance, the primary objective of the Exchange Fund is to directly or indirectly influence the exchange rate of the Hong Kong dollar, and it may also be used to maintain the stability and soundness of Hong Kong's monetary and financial system, thereby preserving Hong Kong's position as an international financial center. The Hong Kong Monetary Authority is accountable to the Financial Secretary for the management and investment of the Exchange Fund, based on the powers conferred by the Financial Secretary and the delegated authority.

# Management of the Foreign Exchange Fund

# Investment Objectives and Portfolio Structure

The Hong Kong Monetary Authority's Exchange Fund Advisory Committee establishes the following investment objectives for the Exchange Fund:

(a) Ensuring capital preservation;  
(b) Ensuring that the entire monetary base is always fully supported by highly liquid U.S. dollar assets;  
(c) Ensuring sufficient liquidity to maintain monetary and financial stability; and  
(d) Striving to maximize investment returns, in accordance with the above (a) to (c), in order to safeguard the fund's long-term purchasing power.

The above objectives comprehensively take into account the statutory purposes of the Exchange Fund and have been reflected in the composition structure and target asset allocation of the Exchange Fund.

The Exchange Fund is generally divided into two main portfolios: the support portfolio and the investment portfolio. The support portfolio holds highly liquid dollar assets that provide full support for the monetary base in accordance with the currency issuance regime. The investment portfolio mainly invests in the bond and stock markets of Organization for Economic Co-operation and Development (OECD) member countries, to ensure the value and long-term purchasing power of assets.

To more effectively manage risks and enhance long-term returns, the Hong Kong Monetary Authority is prudently and gradually diversifying a portion of the Foreign Exchange Fund's assets into a broader range of asset classes, including emerging market and mainland China bonds and equities, private equity (including infrastructure), and real estate. Emerging market and mainland China bonds and equities are held by the investment portfolio, while private equity and real estate investments are held by the long-term growth portfolio. The market value cap of the long-term growth portfolio is set at one-third of the accumulated surplus of the Foreign Exchange Fund, plus the total amount of deposits in the Future Fund and the affiliated companies of the Foreign Exchange Fund that are linked to the long-term growth portfolio.

The Strategic Asset Portfolio was established in 2007 to hold shares in The Hong Kong Exchanges and Clearing Limited purchased by the Exchange Fund account for strategic purposes. Due to the unique nature of this portfolio, its investment performance is not included in the Exchange Fund's performance evaluation.

# Deposits with the Exchange Fund

The Exchange Fund occasionally accepts deposits from fiscal reserves, government funds, and statutory bodies, with interest rates generally linked to the performance of the investment portfolio, except for the Future Fund. The interest rate for deposits in the Future Fund is linked to the performance of the investment portfolio and the long-term growth portfolio, with the actual interest rate depending on the allocation between the two portfolios. At the end of 2018, the allocation of the Future Fund between the investment portfolio and the long-term growth portfolio was approximately 50:50.

# Investment Process

The investment process of the Exchange Fund is based on both strategic asset allocation and tactical asset allocation. Strategic asset allocation refers to the asset allocation reflected in the investment benchmark, which indicates the long-term asset allocation that the Exchange Fund can make to achieve its investment objectives. The Exchange Fund uses strategic allocation as a guideline to carry out tactical asset allocation in order to seek returns that exceed the benchmark. Therefore, the actual allocation often deviates from the benchmark allocation (i.e., the strategic allocation), and the difference between the actual allocation and the benchmark allocation is referred to as "tactical deviation." The Financial Secretary sets the investment benchmark and tracking error limit after consulting the Exchange Fund Advisory Committee, and the Hong Kong Monetary Authority is authorized to determine the strategic asset allocation and set the allowable range of tactical deviation. Portfolio managers can hold positions within the allowable range of tactical deviation to profit from short-term market fluctuations.

# Investment Management

# Direct Investment

The Hong Kong Monetary Authority established the Foreign Exchange Fund Investment Office in August, tasked with the specialized functions of investment and related risk management. The office's staff are responsible for directly managing approximately 72% of the Foreign Exchange Fund's investments, including the entire support portfolio and part of the investment portfolio. These investment portfolios are invested in global fixed-income markets, and the macro risk management strategies of the Foreign Exchange Fund are implemented through derivative instruments.

# Outsourced Investment Manager

In addition to managing assets through internal staff, the Hong Kong Monetary Authority also employs external investment managers to oversee approximately 28% of the Foreign Exchange Fund's assets, including all equity portfolios and other special assets. The purpose of employing external investment managers is to utilize the best professional investment techniques available in the market to invest in the Foreign Exchange Fund, thereby achieving sustainable returns and benefiting from diversified and complementary investment approaches, as well as gaining access to market expertise and professional investment knowledge.

Expenses related to hiring external investment managers include fund management and custody fees, transaction costs, withholding taxes, and other taxes. These expenses vary from year to year and are mainly influenced by market factors.

# Risk Management and Supervision

As the investment environment becomes increasingly complex, the importance of risk management is highlighted. The Hong Kong Monetary Authority has established strict control measures and investment guidelines for both internal and externally hired investment managers, and closely monitors compliance with these guidelines and regulations. The Authority has also strengthened risk assessment to align with the growing diversification of the Foreign Exchange Fund's investments; it also employs risk control tools to evaluate market risks under normal and extremely adverse market conditions. Additionally, the Authority conducts detailed analysis of investment performance factors to identify the causes behind different performance outcomes, thereby assessing how to fully leverage the investment management expertise of both internal and external investment managers.

# Responsible Investment

The HKMA supports responsible investment. For example, the HKMA has adopted the "Principles of Responsible Ownership" published by the Securities and Futures Ordinance Committee. These principles aim to assist investors in determining the best ways to fulfill their ownership responsibilities in investing in Hong Kong-listed companies. In terms of managing the Exchange Fund, the HKMA has established internal guidelines on environmental, social, and governance factors, applicable to the selection, appointment, and supervision of external fund managers. External fund managers appointed to actively manage Hong Kong equity portfolios are required to adhere to the "Principles of Responsible Ownership" when managing such investments. Overall, the HKMA has incorporated environmental, social, and governance factors into its internal procedures for investment and related monitoring activities. The HKMA closely monitors the development of relevant standards on environmental, social, and governance factors and evaluates how these standards can be further integrated into investment processes. In addition, to promote international cooperation on responsible investment, the HKMA has become a member of the non-profit organization FCLTGlobal, which aims to promote business and investment decisions based on long-term goals.

# Performance of the Foreign Exchange Fund

# Financial Markets in 2018

In 2018, various risk factors that had previously been underestimated by the market began to emerge, including the pace of U.S. interest rate normalization, the impact of U.S. government trade policies and protectionism on global trade, and geopolitical risks. As a result, global financial markets experienced significant volatility and adjustments.

The escalating trade dispute between the U.S. and China has caused significant concern among investors. Emerging markets and Hong Kong's stock markets have been repeatedly declining since early February, with the Hang Seng Index falling as much as 27% from its peak in that month. Starting from the fourth quarter, major European and American stock markets also experienced substantial declines, recording double-digit percentage drops. For the entire year of 2018, global stock markets generally declined, with the MSCI Global Index, which covers developed market stocks, dropping by 10.4%, and the MSCI Emerging Markets Index also falling by 16.6%.

In the bond market, U.S. Treasury yields rose broadly in 2018 due to the normalization of U.S. monetary policy. However, the bond market still experienced fluctuations during the year. For example, the 10-year U.S. Treasury yield rose from around 2.5% at the beginning of the year to a seven-year high of 3.2% in November, but softened to 2.7% by year-end, influenced by investors' concerns over the U.S.-China trade dispute and a shift toward more conservative investments.

In the money market, the dollar strengthened throughout the year as it followed the U.S. interest rate hikes. The U.S. dollar index rose by 4.4%, while major currencies such as the euro and the Chinese yuan declined against the dollar by about 5%. Additionally, some emerging markets experienced further currency depreciation due to domestic political and economic instability. For example, the Argentine peso and the Turkish lira fell by about 50% and 30% respectively against the dollar. In contrast, the yen appreciated by 2.7% against the dollar, driven by demand for safe-haven investments.

# 金管局員工

金管局是政府架構的一部分，但按非公務員條款聘請員工，吸引具適當經驗及專門知識的人才。作為公營機構，金管局不斷精簡工作流程，提高效率及成本效益。金管局致力維持精簡靈活的組織架構，並盡可能透過調配現有人手推行新措施及應付不斷增加的工作量。

金管局是提供平等就業機會的僱主，並確保員工能夠在沒有歧視的環境下工作。金管局的平等機會政策適用於聘用、薪酬與福利、表現評核、晉升、調職╱培訓機會及一般行為操守等方面。

金管局聘用、培訓及維持一支專業優秀的工作團隊，以履行政策目標及靈活應對工作要求的轉變。金管局要求其員工維持高水平的操守及道德標準，不論何時都恪守極高的個人行為及操守規範，並以金管局的最佳利益為依歸。

財政司司長透過外匯基金諮詢委員會聽取其轄下管治委員會的意見，並參考市場薪酬水平及做法，決定金管局員工的薪酬及服務條件。薪酬組合包括現金薪酬及公積金，另設一些基本福利。現金薪酬包括每月固定薪酬（即基本薪酬）及根據員工工作表現每年一次過發放的浮動薪酬。

財政司司長每年檢討金管局員工薪酬時，會透過外匯基金諮詢委員會聽取其轄下管治委員會的建議，並考慮管治委員會對金管局過去一年的表現評估、獨立人力資源顧問公司進行的金融業薪酬調查結果，以及其他相關因素。個別工作表現優秀的員工的薪酬亦可能獲得特別調整，以保持其薪酬競爭力。

金管局按個別員工的工作表現，分配獲批准用作調整年度固定薪酬及浮動薪酬的款項；而適用於負責投資的員工的浮動薪酬制度，則旨在加強其投資表現與薪酬的連繫。助理總裁及以上職級員工的固定薪酬調整及浮動薪酬的發放，是由財政司司長經參考管治委員會的意見後批准，有關員工在會議討論到其薪酬的議案時會避席。主管及以下職級員工的固定薪酬調整及浮動薪酬的發放，則由金管局總裁根據財政司司長授權，並按照獲批准用作支付薪酬的整筆款項來決定。

# Stay in touch with the public

# Media Relations and Social Media

The Hong Kong Monetary Authority maintains close contact with the media to enhance transparency and promote public understanding of its policies and work. In 2018, the Authority organized 96 public media events, including 21 press conferences, 11 on-site interviews, and 64 other public activities. In addition, 39 media interviews were arranged, and 462 bilingual press releases were issued. A large number of media inquiries were also handled daily.

To enhance public understanding of the Hong Kong Monetary Authority's main functions, the Authority organizes media briefings and workshops for local and overseas media. The topics covered include a variety of themes such as the currency board system (HKD-USD linkage mechanism), financial technology development, green finance, and infrastructure financing. In addition to enriching the content of its existing YouTube channel and LinkedIn page, the Authority launched an official Facebook page in July to further leverage social media for enhanced communication with the public.

# Public Inquiry

The Public Inquiry Service is an effective channel for enhancing the public's understanding of the HKMA's main functions and operations. In 2018, a total of 9,950 inquiries were handled, with approximately half relating to banking policies and regulations, banking consumer matters, and notes and coins, particularly the Coin Collection Scheme, banking products and services, guidelines and announcements related to the banking sector, the fast payment system "FPS", virtual banking, and the 2018 Hong Kong New Banknotes Series.

# Publications

In addition to the Hong Kong Monetary Authority's Annual Report, the Authority published two semi-annual reports on the monetary and financial stability situation and four quarterly reports in 2018. It also regularly updates the data in the Financial Data Monthly, providing the latest and specialized information and analysis on monetary, banking, and economic matters in Hong Kong. Furthermore, the Authority published 13 "Hong Kong Monetary Thought" articles, explaining various specialized topics related to its work.

# Hong Kong Monetary Authority Website

The Hong Kong Monetary Authority's official website (www.hkma.gov.hk) provides more than 60,000 pages of English and both simplified and traditional Chinese versions of information, making it convenient for the public to access the latest information from the HKMA. The website also contains the "List of Recognized Institutions and Their Local Representatives" and the "List of Recognized Institution Securities Staff" kept under Section 20 of the Banking Ordinance, as well as the "List of Licensed Value-Added Payment Tool Operators" kept under the Payment Systems and Value-Added Payment Tools Ordinance. The website features dedicated thematic pages and prominent quick links to remind the public of the HKMA's new measures, such as "FPS PayMe," as well as important and timely matters, such as being vigilant against telephone fraud and the locations where cash collection vehicles are parked under the coin collection scheme.

To promote the implementation of open application programming interfaces (APIs) in the banking sector, the Hong Kong Monetary Authority (HKMA) has taken the lead by starting to provide open APIs on its website from July, making it easier for the public to access important HKMA information. The first batch of 50 open API data sets was successfully launched in July, covering areas most frequently accessed by the public, such as statistical data on the banking system and the Exchange Fund, as well as press releases and cash-in-transit vehicle schedules. The remaining 80 data sets will be rolled out in phases before the middle of 2019. To further facilitate public access to the latest news and information about the HKMA on the website, the HKMA is currently comprehensively revising the website's design and content to make it more user-friendly. The newly redesigned website is expected to be launched within 2019.

The HKMA actively promotes the development and application of open APIs.

The Hong Kong Monetary Authority Information Centre is located on the 55th floor of Two IFC, introducing the public to the functions of the Monetary Authority and enhancing public understanding of monetary and banking matters. The Information Centre consists of two parts: an exhibition hall and a library. It is open to the public for six days a week. The exhibition hall introduces the Monetary Authority's work, as well as the development of Hong Kong's currency and banking sector. It also provides reading materials and exhibits for research on Hong Kong's currency, banking, and financial affairs.

The Currency Exhibition Hall at the Information Center introduces the design, anti-counterfeiting features, production process, and other interesting facts about Hong Kong banknotes and coins. It is made up of 2,018 transparent cubic blocks crafted from shredded banknotes that are no longer suitable for circulation. It complements another mosaic artwork in the exhibition hall, which is made from Hong Kong coins. The newly renovated Currency Exhibition Hall reopened on August 16.

The Information Center provides guided tours for visitors. During the year, the Information Center welcomed over 59,000 visitors and provided more than 580 guided tour sessions for schools and other groups (Figure 3). Since its opening in December 2003, the Information Center has cumulatively received over 705,000 visitors. The library adjacent to the exhibition hall houses more than 26,000 books, journals, and other publications for research on topics such as Hong Kong currency, banking, finance, and central banking. # Hong Kong Monetary Authority Staff

The Hong Kong Monetary Authority is part of the government structure but employs staff under non-civil service terms to attract individuals with appropriate experience and expertise. As a public institution, the Hong Kong Monetary Authority continuously streamlines its work processes to enhance efficiency and cost-effectiveness. It is committed to maintaining a lean and flexible organizational structure and strives to implement new measures and cope with increasing workloads by optimally utilizing its existing workforce.

The Hong Kong Monetary Authority is an employer that provides equal employment opportunities and ensures that employees can work in an environment free from discrimination. The Authority's equal opportunity policy applies to recruitment, compensation and benefits, performance evaluation, promotion, transfer/training opportunities, and general conduct.

The HKMA employs, trains, and maintains a professional and excellent workforce to fulfill its policy objectives and flexibly respond to changes in work requirements. The Office of the Fund Management was established on August 1st, taking over the investment and related risk management functions previously handled by the Reserve Management Department and the Risk Management and Supervision Department. # Salary and Benefits Policy and Salary Review Mechanism

The Financial Secretary seeks the views of the Hong Kong Monetary Authority's Board of Directors through the Exchange Fund Advisory Committee, and considers market salary levels and practices to determine the salaries and service conditions of the Hong Kong Monetary Authority's staff. The salary package includes cash compensation and a provident fund, along with some basic benefits. Cash compensation consists of a fixed monthly salary (i.e., basic salary) and a performance-based lump-sum payment issued annually according to the staff member's work performance.

When the Financial Secretary reviews the salaries of Hong Kong Monetary Authority (HKMA) employees annually, they seek advice from the Hong Kong Monetary Authority's Board of Directors through the Exchange Fund Advisory Committee. This advice takes into account the Board's evaluation of the HKMA's performance over the past year, the results of a salary survey in the financial sector conducted by an independent human resources consultancy, and other relevant factors. Individual employees with outstanding work performance may also receive special adjustments to their salaries to maintain their competitiveness in the market.

The Hong Kong Monetary Authority allocates the approved amounts used to adjust annual fixed and variable salaries based on individual employees' performance. The variable salary system for employees responsible for investments is designed to strengthen the link between their investment performance and compensation. For fixed salary adjustments and variable salary disbursements of senior management and above, the Financial Secretary approves them after consulting the Governance Committee, and such employees will not attend meetings discussing their salary proposals. For fixed salary adjustments and variable salary disbursements of staff at the managerial level and below, the Chief Executive of the Hong Kong Monetary Authority decides based on the Financial Secretary's authorization and in accordance with the approved lump sum for salary payments.

# 金融管理專員及外匯基金諮詢委員會轄下的審核委員會就財務報表而須承擔的責任

金融管理專員須負責按照香港會計師公會頒布的《香港財務報告準則》及行政長官在《外匯基金條例》第7條下所發出的指示擬備真實而中肯的財務報表，及落實其認為必要的內部控制， 使財務報表不存有因欺詐或錯誤而導致的重大錯誤陳述。

在擬備財務報表時，金融管理專員須負責評估集團持續經營的能力，以及在適用情況下披露與持續經營有關的事項，並以持續經營作為會計基礎。

外匯基金諮詢委員會轄下的審核委員會負責監督集團的財務報告過程。

# 審計師就財務報表審計而須承擔的責任

我的目標是就整體財務報表是否不存有任何因欺詐或錯誤而導致的重大錯誤陳述取得合理保證，並發出包括我意見的審計師報告。合理保證是高水平的保證，但不能確保按審計署審計準則進行的審計定能發現所存有的任何重大錯誤陳述。錯誤陳述可以由欺詐或錯誤引起，如果合理預期它們個別或滙總起來可能影響財務報表使用者所作出的經濟決定，則會被視作重大錯誤陳述。

在根據審計署審計準則進行審計的過程中，我會運用專業判斷並秉持專業懷疑態度。我亦會：

- 識別和評估因欺詐或錯誤而導致財務報表存有重大錯誤陳述的風險；設計及執行審計程序以應對這些風險；以及取得充足和適當的審計憑證，作為我意見的基礎。由於欺詐可能涉及串謀、偽造、蓄意遺漏、虛假陳述，或凌駕內部控制的情況，因此未能發現因欺詐而導致重大錯誤陳述的風險，較未能發現因錯誤而導致者為高；
- 了解與審計相關的內部控制，以設計適當的審計程序。然而，此舉並非旨在對集團內部控制的有效性發表意見；
- 評價金融管理專員所採用的會計政策是否恰當，以及其作出的會計估計和相關資料披露是否合理；
- 判定金融管理專員以持續經營作為會計基礎的做法是否恰當，並根據所得的審計憑證，判定是否存在與事件或情況有關，而且可能對集團持續經營的能力構成重大疑慮的重大不確定性。如果我認為存在重大不確定性，則有必要在審計師報告中請使用者留意財務報表中的相關資料披露。假若所披露的相關資料不足，我便須發出非無保留意見的審計師報告。我的結論是基於截至審計師報告日止所取得的審計憑證。然而，未來事件或情況可能導致集團不能繼續持續經營；
- 評價財務報表的整體列報方式、結構和內容，包括披露資料，以及財務報表是否中肯反映交易和事項；及
- 就集團中實體或業務活動的財務資料獲取充足和適當的審計憑證，以對財務報表發表意見。我負責指導、監督和執行集團審計。我對我的審計意見承擔全部責任。

我會與外匯基金諮詢委員會轄下的審核委員會溝通計劃的審計範圍和時間以及重大審計發現等事項，包括我在審計期間識別出內部控制的任何重大缺陷。

我亦會向外匯基金諮詢委員會轄下的審核委員會提交聲明，說明我已符合有關獨立性的相關道德要求，並與他們溝通所有被合理認為可能會影響我獨立性的關係和其他事項，以及在適用的情況下，相關的防範措施。

從與外匯基金諮詢委員會轄下的審核委員會溝通的事項中，我會決定哪些事項對本期財務報表的審計最為重要，因而構成關鍵審計事項。我會在審計師報告中描述這些事項，除非法律法規不允許對某件事項作出公開披露，或在極端罕見的情況下，因為有合理預期在我報告中溝通某事項而造成的負面後果將會超過其產生的公眾利益而我決定不應在報告中溝通該事項。

# Fair Value Measurement of Financial Assets and Financial Liabilities

Please refer to Notes 2.5, 2.6, and 40.1 of the financial statements.

As of December 31, 2018, the Group's financial assets measured at fair value totaled HKD 36,935.89 billion, while financial liabilities amounted to HKD 11,338.29 billion.

The total amount of these financial assets is HKD 275.631 billion, mainly comprising non-listed investment funds.

Given the significant amount involved and the estimates, the valuation of financial assets and financial liabilities carried at fair value is a key audit matter.

The audit procedures for the valuation of financial assets and financial liabilities measured at fair value include:

- Understand the valuation processes for different categories of financial assets and financial liabilities, including related monitoring measures;
- Evaluate and test monitoring measures, including application-level monitoring measures for computer systems;
- Obtain confirmations regarding the valuation, existence, rights and obligations, and completeness of financial assets and financial liabilities;
- If market quotations are used, verify the prices based on independent sources;
- If the parameters used in the valuation methods are based on observable market data, evaluate whether the valuation method is appropriate and whether the related assumptions are reasonable, and verify the parameters based on independent sources; and
- If the parameters used in the valuation methods are not based on observable market data, evaluate whether the valuation method is appropriate, and assess whether the related assumptions and parameters are reasonable.

# Valuation of Investment Properties Measured at Fair Value

Please refer to Notes 2.12, 20, and 21 of the financial statements.

- Assess the independence and qualifications of the valuers; and  
- Evaluate whether the valuation methods are appropriate, and whether the related assumptions and parameters are reasonable.

# Responsibilities of Auditors in Auditing Financial Statements

My objective is to obtain reasonable assurance that the financial statements, as a whole, are free from material misstatements due to fraud or error, and to issue an auditor's report that includes my opinion. Reasonable assurance is a high level of assurance, but it does not guarantee that an audit conducted in accordance with auditing standards will necessarily detect any material misstatements that may exist. Misstatements can arise from fraud or error, and they are considered material misstatements if, individually or in aggregate, they are likely to influence the economic decisions of users of the financial statements.

During the audit process conducted in accordance with the Audit Office's auditing standards, I will apply professional judgment and maintain a professional skeptical attitude. I will also:

Identify and assess the risk that financial statements may contain material misstatements due to fraud or error; design and perform audit procedures to address these risks; and obtain sufficient and appropriate audit evidence to support my opinion.
